item.title: Using Caps-Lock as a Compose key in XFCE4
item.description: Why not take that useless key, and make it useful? The Compose Key—formerly present on many Unix keyboards of old—isn’t present on most modern laptops. In XFCE, this is a little more cumbersome than Gnome, since there isn’t a graphical interface for setxkbmap, but these two commands will swap the Caps lock for a compose key: setxkbmap -option ctrl:nocaps # disables caps lock setxkbmap -option compose:caps # sets caps key to compose To make this active at login, you can add two entries to your “Session and Startup” -> “Application Autostart” available under the Settings Manager.
